715407f-b.text:
W. 125th Street, (left of No. 1 and 2) eastward across Morningside Avenue from an open area called Roosevelt Square. To the right is Hancock Place, extending southward to Hancock Square where it runs into St. Nicholas Avenue. The "0'Reilly" warehouse seen at the extreme right is at the N.E. corner of St. Nicholas Avenue and W. 123rd Street. The Ninth Avenue "El" is shown crossing 125th Street at Eighth Avenue. View 2 is in a northeastward direction and shows mainly the buildings on the north side of 125th Street between Morningside and St. Nicholas
Avenue.
October 1920
View 2: June 1928
Geo. L. Balgue

721717f-c.text:
Morningside Avenue, west side, north from W. 125th Street, and showing at the N.W.corner of this point, St. Josephs Roman 9atholic Church. To the rear of same is the Convent occupying a site at the S.W. corner of W.126th Street (formerly Lawrence) Street. This church was erected here in 1860 as the German Church of Manhattanville.
Views 1 and 2 are similar,while No. 3 shows the church
front and the adjoining parish house. Buildings shown to the left of
the latter bear Nofd 409 to 413 W. 125th Street.
The open area in the foreground is Roosevelt Square and
is formed by the crossing of several thoroughferes at this point.
April 1, 1938
Views 2 and 3 July 27, 1929
P.L.Sperr

721715f-b.text:
Morningside Avenue, west side, south from W. 124th Street, showing a row of tenements between 123rd to 124th Streets. South of same is Morningside Park. The westerly margin of the latter is Morningside Drive with numerous apartment houses upon same. View No. 2 is the same area at a latter date and shows the absence of tenements exclusive of that at the S.W. corner of 124th Street. This, according to the New York Times of October 5th, 1938, is shortly to follow; being included in demoliton of structures owned by John D. Rockefeller and consisting of No's. 400 to 432 W. 124th Street. Subsequently the only remaining building in the lwoer half of this block will be the Lincoln School on 123rd Street.
June 1930
View 2:April 1, 1938.
Geo. L. Palgue
P. L. Snerr

715409f-a.text:
415 West 125th Street, north side, west of Morningside Ave. Building
shown is a frame house.
June 21, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

721716f-a.text:
Morningside Ave., east side, from Hancock Place (left) to West 124th Street (right), and showing the east side of St. Nicholas Ave., between West 124th and 123rd Streets in the background. On the right appears Nos. 358350 West 124th Street.
June 21, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
721716f-a.folder: Morningside Avenue & Hancock Place, Manhattan, NY

715406f-a.text:
W. 125th Street, north side, east from a point westward of Morningside Avenue and across same, showing St. Josephs R.C.
Church at the N.W. corner.
In the background and crossing this thoroughfare is the Ninth Avenue "El" running on Eighth Avenue at this point.
March 19, 1936.
P.L. Sperr

1508421-a.title: 124th Street (West) - Morningside Avenue, north side -
1508421-a.folder: 124th Street (West) - Morningside Avenue, north side -, Manhattan, NY

715332f-a.text:
W. 124th Street, west from and across Morningside Avenue. The buildings at the left are the property of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and are about to be demolished according to the New York Times of October 5th, 1938. Opposite same is the 2 story business structure that was recently demolished and the site included in the new Station
'p" Post Office that bears No. 2 LaSalle Street.
September 1928.
Geo. L. Balgue

715333f-b.text:
West 124th Street, west from Morningside Avenue, showing a 2 story structure adjoining the N.W. corner which will be included in the new site of Station"F", United States Post Office according to the New York Times of March 22, 1938. This structure, formerly occupied by the Willard Storage Battery Company extends thru the block to front on La Salle Place. This office is now located at No. 309-11 W. 125th Street and from which it will shortly remove
to this location (No. 2-4 La Salle Place).
Views 2 and 3 are eastward views of the same area.
May 4, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3.
P. L. Sperr
